document.docAuthor: Ludoški, Jasmina & Francuski, Ljubinka & Vujić, Ante & Milankov, Vesna
document.docTitle: The Cheilosia canicularis group (Diptera: Syrphidae): species delimitation and evolutionary relationships based on wing geometric morphometrics

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Cheilosia canicularis group (Diptera: Syrphidae): species delimitation and evolutionary relationships based on wing geometric morphometrics

paragraph.docTitle:
The
Cheilosia canicularis
group ( Diptera : Syrphidae ): species delimitation and evolutionary relationships based on wing geometric morphometrics

subSection.paragraph:
JASMINA LUDO Š KI
1
, LJUBINKA FRANCUSKI , ANTE VUJI Ć & VESNA MILANKOV

University of
Novi Sad , Faculty of Sciences , Department of Biology and Ecology, Trg Dositeja Obradovica 2, 21000
Novi Sad , Serbia . E-mail: 1 jasminal@ib.ns.ac.yu

A landmark-based geometric morphometric approach was used to assess differences in the size and shape of wing among/within three species of the
Cheilosia canicularis
group ( Diptera : Syrphidae ):
C. canicularis
,
C. himantopus
and
C. orthotricha
. Wing size and shape variation was observed from 25, 176 and 41 specimens of
C. canicularis , C. himantopus
and
C. orthotricha ,
respectively, collected from six localities on the Balkan Peninsula. Significant differences in wing size were obtained among the analysed species and canonical variate analysis showed that wing shape was sufficiently different to allow the correct classification of 73% individuals of
C. canicularis
, 80% of
C. orthotricha
and 94% of
C. himantopus
, and clear delimitation of the species pairs
C. canicularis
/
C. orthotricha
and
C. himantopus
/
C. orthotricha
. In all analysed species, the consistent sex dimorphism in wing shape was observed indicating that female specimens had shorter and broader wings than males. The UPGMA cluster analysis based on squared Mahalanobis distances revealed close accordance with previously published phylogenetic relationships of these species indicated by allozyme and DNA sequence data analysis. Our results suggested that wing parameters contain useful information in quantification phenotypic variation and identification of species in this challenging group for taxonomy and systematics.

Key words:
Cheilosia canicularis
,
C. himantopus
,
C. orthotricha
, species identification, phenotypic variability, wing geometric morphometrics

The genus
Cheilosia Meigen, 1822
( Syrphidae , Diptera ) is the largest genus of European hoverflies with more than 175 European species ( Speight 2007 ). It is primarily distributed in the Palaearctic, with the highest diversity in the forest habitats, especially in broad-leaved woodlands ( Vujić 1996 ). This paper focused on
Cheilosia canicularis (Panzer)
,
C. himantopus (Panzer)
and
C. orthotricha Vujić & Claussen
, a group of species belonging to a broadly defined the
C. canicularis
group that comprises two additional species,
C. japonica
Herve- Bazin and
C. yesonica Matsumura ( Barkalov 2002 )
. The species
C. canicularis , C. himantopus
and
C. orthotricha
have throughout Palaearctic distribution, while the other two occur only in Japan ( Peck 1988 ).

The taxonomy of the
C. canicularis
group was a matter of disagreement. The complex relationship between
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
has generated controversy regarding taxonomic rank. Since it was described in 1801, the
C. canicularis
species has been known under number of synonyms ( Vujić & Claussen 1994 ; Stuke & Claussen 2000 ). Taxonomic difficulties in the correct identification of these two species were caused by low levels of phenotypic variation and the great similarity in larval development ( Stuke & Claussen 2000 ; Stuke 2000). Due to these, it has been hypothesized that the taxon is one species with two generations ( Vujić & Claussen 1994 ) or it is indeed two evolutionary independent units ( Stuke & Claussen 2000 ). The nomenclatural status of
C. himantopus
was recently clarified by Stuke & Claussen (2000) based on detailed study of the morphological characters and ecology of both adult and immature specimens. Given the taxonomic dilemma more detailed analyses of biology ( Vujić & Šikoparija 2001 ), morphology ( Stuke 1995 , 2000; Vujić 1996 ; Stuke & Claussen 2000 ; Vujić & Šikoparija 2001 ) and molecular variation ( Stuke & Brückner 2001 ;
Milankov et al. 2005
) were performed. Beside diagnostic morphological characters of adults (such as length of aristal hairs, specific hypandrium structure and distribution of pilosity on tergits III and IV in females) for identification and separation of species of the
C. canicularis
group provided by Stuke and Claussen (2000) , it was observed that on the Balkan Peninsula female specimens of
C. himantopus
lack black hairs on the mesonotum, while
C. canicularis
has intermixed black and yellow hairs ( Vujić & Šikoparija 2001 ). Adults of analysed species of the
C. canicularis
group are active from early spring to late summer; a flight period of
C. orthotricha
is from February to July,
C. himantopus
from April to August and
C. canicularis
from June to September ( Vujić & Claussen 1994 ; Speight 2007 ). It has been observed that larvae of both species
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
develop in petiole tissues and the rhizome of
Petasites spp.
( Stuke & Claussen 2000 ; Vujić & Šikoparija 2001 ) and that females of
C. himantopus
ovipositing on leaf bud in late spring, while
C. canicularis
laid eggs on the leaves in late summer and early autumn ( Vujić & Šikoparija 2001 ). Finally, in spite of very low level of interspecific genetic variability revealed by analyses of molecular markers ( Stuke & Brückner 2001 ;
Milankov et al. 2005
) the boundaries of the genetic units represented by
C. canicularis
,
C. himantopus
and
C. orthotricha
species were well defined based on diagnostic allozyme loci and species-specific mitochondrial COI haplotypes (
Milankov et al. 2005
).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 1. Map of the Balkan Peninsula. Origin of the analysed populations: 1. Eastern Alps (Slovenia, SLO; E 13º30’–14º40’, N 46º15’); 2. Fruška Gora Mt (Serbia, FG; E 19º50’, N 45º10’); 3. Homoljske planine Mt (Serbia, HPL; E 21º55’, N 44º22’); 4. Kopaonik Mt (Serbia, KOP; E 20º40’, N 43º15’); 5. Durmitor Mt (Montenegro, DUR; E 19º00’, N 43º11’); 6. Jahorina Mt (Bosnia and Herzegovina, BIH; E 18º35’, N 43º43’).

FIGURE 2. The locations of ten landmarks on a right wing of the
C. canicularis
group selected for geometric morphometric analysis.

FIGURE 3. Boxplot of centroid size of populations of the
C. canicularis
group with the mean, standard error and standard deviation illustrating intra- and interspecific variation in wing size.

subSection.paragraph:
However, subtle phenotypic variation at intra- and interpopulation levels of focal species of the
C. canicularis
group has not been performed. Since geometric morphometrics was confirmed as a powerful tool in taxonomy and systematics of insects (e.g. Pretorius 2005 ;
Villemant et al. 2007
) and hoverflies (
Milankov et al. 2008
; J. Ludoški, unpublished), the usefulness of wing landmarks for delimitation of species of the
C. canicularis
group was examined. Additionally, studies of wing measurements can lead us better understanding of phenotypic diversity and taxonomy of closely related species of the
C. canicularis
group. Thus, landmarkbased geometric morphometrics have been used: 1. to identify species of the
C. canicularis
group based on morphometric parameters (shape and size) of right wing, 2. to quantify intra- and interspecific variation, 3. to analyse sexual dimorphism, and 4. to analyse evolutionary relationships among species of the
C. canicularis
group.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. Scatterplot of individual scores from the CVA showing shape differentiation between species of the
C. canicularis
group. The amount of variation explained by each axis is in parentheses.

subSection.paragraph: Sample collection

Samples of ten populations of the
Cheilosia canicularis
group species (
C. canicularis
41 specimens ,
C. himantopus
176 and
C. orthotricha
25) for the geometric morphometric analysis were collected from six regions on the Balkan Peninsula : Eastern Alps ( Slovenia , SLO), Jahorina Mt ( Bosnia and Herzegovina , BIH), Fruška gora Mt ( Serbia , FG), Homoljske planine Mt ( Serbia , HPL), Kopaonik Mt ( Serbia , KOP) and Durmitor Mt (Montenegro, DUR) over several years (1984-2001) ( Tab. 1 ; Fig. 1 ). Analysed specimens of
C. canicularis
were collected during July and August ,
C. himantopus
from April to June and one field trip in August on both Kopaonik Mt and Durmitor Mt , and
C. orthotricha
from end of March to June. Only several analysed individuals of sympatric populations of
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
from Kopaonik Mt and Durmitor Mt were collected at the same date (in August )
.
Geometric morphometric analysis

Morphometric analysis was carried out on the right wing of 242 ( 110 males and 132 females ) specimens and each wing was mounted separately in Hoyer’s medium between microscope slides. Wing images were captured using a stereomicroscope Leica MZ12.5 and attached video camera Leica DFC320 connected to a PC computer. Data for wing size and shape were obtained by positioning ten landmarks at vein intersections or terminations on digitized wings using TpsDig software (version 1.40; Rohlf 2004 , freeware at http:// life.bio.sunysb.edu/morph/) ( Fig. 2 ). This program express landmarks as x,y coordinates in Cartesian space.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. Scatterplot of individual scores from the CVA showing shape differentiation between A) male, and B) female individuals of
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
. The amount of variation explained by each axis is in parentheses.

FIGURE 6. Boxplot of centroid size of species of the
C. canicularis
group with the mean, standard error and standard deviation illustrating sexual size dimorphism.

FIGURE 7. Scatterplot of individual scores from the CVA showing shape differentiation between sexes of species of the
C. canicularis
group. The amount of variation explained by each axis is in parentheses.

FIGURE 8. Thin-plate spline reconstruction representing negative and positive deformations of mean shape between genders along the CV1 axis. Deformation grids are exaggerated × 3. Numbers in the deformation grids refer to landmarks shown in figure 2.

subSection.paragraph: Both centroid size and w matrix were obtained utilizing TpsRelw software (version 1.44; Rohlf 2006 , freeware at http://life.bio.sunysb.edu/morph/), multiple regressions and visualization of deformation grids were computed with the TpsRegr 1.31 ( Rohlf 2005 , freeware at http://life.bio.sunysb.edu/morph/), and all statistical analyses were calculated using Statistica for Windows (version 7.1).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9. UPGMA phenogram based on the squared Mahalanobis distances of populations of the
C. canicularis
group.

subSection.paragraph:
The ANOVA on centroid size of the wings showed a highly significant difference among species of the
C. canicularis
group ( F (2,239) = 47.90, p= 0.000; for all pairwise comparisons post hoc Tukey test p <0.001);
C. himantopus
had the biggest wings, being followed by
C. canicularis
and
C. orthotricha .
Also, wing size differed significantly among five conspecific populations of
C. himantopus
( F (4,171) = 11.73, p= 0.000) and two of
C. canicularis
( F (1,39) = 8.78; p= 0.005), but not among three populations of
C. orthotricha
( F (2,22) = 1.90, p= 0.172; post hoc Tukey tests were not significant) ( Fig. 3 ). Tukey's post hoc test revealed that population of
C. himantopus
from Eastern Alps had significantly smaller wing size than individuals of conspecific populations from Fruška Gora, Homoljske planine and Kopaonik Mts.

Canonical variate analysis (CVA) conducted on the w matrix evidenced that 73% individuals of
C. canicularis
(11 out of 41 specimens were classified as
C. himantopus
), 80% of
C. orthotricha
(five out of 25 specimens were classified as
C. himantopus
) and 94% of
C. himantopus
( 11 specimens were misclassified - three as
C. orthotricha
and eight as
C. canicularis
) were correctly classified (overall classification success was 89%) indicating that wing shape has a certain interspecific discrimination power. The two axis extracted by the CVA of w matrix were highly significant and contribute to shape differentiation among species (Wilks’ Λ=0.326, F (32,448) =10.51, p <0.000). The first canonical axes accounting 61.2% of total variation clearly separated
C. canicularis
and
C. orthotricha .
The
C. himantopus
species appeared as an intermediate group and partially overlapped with other analysed species ( Fig. 4 ). The CVA indicated that male specimens of
C. canicularis
from Durmitor Mt were mixed with
C. himantopus
males ( Fig. 5A ), while nearly all female specimens of
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
were separated in two distinct clusters except
C. himantopus
from Kopaonik Mt ( Fig. 5B ). Based on wing shape, male specimens of
C. canicularis
and
C. himatopus
on both localities Kopaonik and Durmitor Mts were clearly different, while females were slightly overlapped ( Figs. 5A, B ).

When sexes were considered separately, intraspecific sexual size dimorphism was detected; male specimens had larger wings than female of
C. canicularis
( F (1,39) =0.92, p =0.34) and
C. himantopus
( F (1,174) =3.96, p <0.05) contrary to
C. orthotricha
( F (1,23) =2.10, p =0.16) ( Fig. 6 ). Sexual dimorphism in shape was highly significant in all analysed species (
C. canicularis
: Wilks’ Λ=0.007, F (48,66) =5.88, p <0.000;
C. himantopus
: Wilks’ Λ=0.025, F (144,1209) =5.01, p <0.000;
C. orthotricha
: Wilks’ Λ=0.00002, F (80,28) =2.94, p <0.001) ( Fig. 7 ). The CVA provided discrimination between sexes of all three analysed species by the first canonical axis, which accounted for 83.8% of the total shape variation. The thin-plate spline visualizations showed that most of the shape changes were associated with differences in relative positions of landmarks 2, 3, 5 and 6, which influence the wing’s length and width ( Fig. 8 ).

Analysis of interpopulation variation within each species revealed that there were no significant differences in wing shape among conspecific populations of analysed species of the
C. canicularis
group. The UPGMA cluster analyses of the squared Mahalanobis distances computed from w matrix clustered
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
in the same branch while
C. orthotricha
was the most divergent species ( Fig. 9 ).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1.
Cheilosia canicularis
group: species, populations and sample size.

subSection.paragraph:
The present study investigated the morphological differentiation pattern among three species of the
Cheilosia canicularis
group using landmark-based geometric morphometric analysis. We found considerable interspecific differences in wing size and shape. The smallest wings of
C. orthotricha
had clearly distinct shape from
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
wings. In comparison with this, canonical variate analysis revealed lower, but also important, phenotypic differentiation between
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
. Since it has been known that wing shape exhibits a high heritability in nature, as it was reported for
Drosophila species
and
Apis mellifera
(e.g. Bitner-Mathé & Klaczko 1999 ;
Monteiro et al. 2002
;
Moraes et al . 2004
), morphological differentiation observed among the taxa of the
C. canicularis
group indicated that the analysed species have independent evolution. Moreover, observed divergent wing shape phenotypes in sympatric populations from Durmitor and Kopaonik Mts clearly demonstrated
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
as evolutionary independent entities. Our findings are in general agreement with previously published molecular and genetic studies. Namely, analysis of allozyme nuclear loci provided eight diagnostic loci for delineating
C. orthotricha
from the other two species, while species-specific alleles at the Est locus differentiated all three species of the
C. canicularis
group (
Milankov et al . 2005
). Similarly, low but consistent molecular differentiation between
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus
was observed in mtDNA COI (
Milankov et al . 2005
) and COII ( Stuke & Brückner 2001 ) gene sequences. Lower intraspecific variation and modarate but significant interspecific differences in wing shape supporting hypothesis that closely related species
C. himantopus
and
C. canicularis
were splited recently (ca. 0.3–0.6 Mya,
Milankov et al . 2005
).

Geometric morphometric analysis discovered the existence of morphological variation between genders within the species of the
C. canicularis
group. Substantial male-biased sexual dimorphism in wing size was registered for
C. himantopus
, although female-biased sexual size dimorphisam is far more common among invertebrates and it was detected for about 80% of investigated species of instects ( Teder & Tammaru 2005 ). Significant differences were found between males and females of all three analysed species for wing shape. In shape terms, female wings are shorter and broader than male wings across all three analysed species. It was documented that homologous landmarks tend to have opposite displacement in females and males. For instance, landmarks 2 and 3 were more posterior positioned and landmark 6 was more anterior in female than in male. In females landmark 5 had distal displacement in comparison with more proximal position in males as well ( Fig. 8 ). The consistency of this pattern of dimorphism is also evident in other
Cheilosia species
(J. Ludoški, unpublished). Wing shape differences between the two sexes might be induced by differences between males and females in reproductive roles, since aerodynamic performance and courtship song in dipteran species are likely to be affected by wing shape (
Birdsall et al . 2000
). In addition, it has been suggested that gender differences represent a developmental constraint on wing shape in
Drosophila melanogaster (
Gilchrist et al . 2000
)
.

The UPGMA dendrogram obtained from wing shape parameters provided evidence of phenetic divergence between the evolutionary distinct species
C. orthotricha
and closely related species
C. canicularis
and
C. himantopus .
Phenetic relationships presented herein were compatible with phylogenetic relationships of populations of the
C. canicularis
group constructed based on allozyme (
Milankov et al . 2005
), and COI mtDNA and nuclear DNA data (28S rRNA gene) (
Ståhls et al . 2004
). A similarity between phenetic and phylogenetic relationships suggesting that wing shape might be of phylogenetic significance within this species group and that there is an association between the extent of phenotypic evolution and genetic changes.

This work was supported by the Ministry of Science of Serbia , Grant Number 143006B and the Provincial Secretariat for Science and Technological Development (Maintenance of biodiversity – “Hot spots” on the Balkan and Iberian Peninsula). J. L. and Lj. F. are supported by a PhD fellowship from Ministry of Science of Serbia .
